data.title: Today in History, December 15, 1966: Walt Disney died
data.meta_description: On Dec. 15, 1966, movie producer and entertainment mogul Walt Disney died in Los Angeles at age 65.
data.text:
Today is Dec. 15. On this date:

1791

The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, went into effect following ratification by Virginia.

1864

The two-day Battle of Nashville began during the Civil War as Union forces commanded by Maj. Gen. George H. Thomas attacked Confederate troops led by Gen. John Bell Hood; the result was a resounding Northern victory.

1890

Sioux Indian Chief Sitting Bull and 11 other tribe members were killed in Grand River, South Dakota, during a confrontation with Indian police.

1938

Groundbreaking for the Jefferson Memorial took place in Washington, D.C. with President Franklin D. Roosevelt taking part in the ceremony.

1939

The Civil War motion picture epic “Gone with the Wind,” starring Vivien Leigh and Clark Gable, had its world premiere in Atlanta.

1944

A single-engine plane carrying bandleader Glenn Miller, a major in the U.S. Army Air Forces, disappeared over the English Channel while en route to Paris.

1960

Teflon-coated skillets first went on sale, at Macy’s flagship store in New York City.

1966

Movie producer Walt Disney died in Los Angeles at age 65.

Our history: Locals had hand in making Disneyland a reality

1967

The Silver Bridge between Gallipolis, Ohio, and Point Pleasant, West Virginia, collapsed into the Ohio River, killing 46 people.

1978

President Jimmy Carter announced he would grant diplomatic recognition to Communist China on New Year’s Day and sever official relations with Taiwan.

1993

Steven Spielberg’s epic Holocaust film “Schindler’s List” opened nationwide after a premiere in Washington, D.C.

1995

European Union leaders meeting in Madrid, Spain, chose “euro” as the name of the new single European currency.
